abstracts.cdata!:
The Earthquake Rehabilitation and
            Reconstruction Project's outcome and achievement of
            project objectives is rated as satisfactory. However, there
            were several problems during the first three years of the
            project with the selection and work of the consultants who
            assisted Housing Development Administration with design and
            construction supervision for the four main construction
            components. These difficulties significantly contributed to
            the initial implementation delays. Furthermore, there was
            poor government commitment to the institutional components
            attempting to strengthen Turkey's preparedness for
            future earthquakes. The lessons learned from this project
            include: 1) Give preventive and institutional development
            measures a more prominent role. 2) Maintain reasonable
            Quality at Entry even for urgent projects. 3) Local
            involvement is key to success. 4) Seek to limit the number
            of sectors included. 5) Avoid extensions. It would have been
            better to close the project in 1996 and identify new
            operations in response to future disasters on the basis of
            the merits of those cases.
